title: Creating Your First FRC Robot Project

sections.title: Introduction to FRC Projects
sections.content:
An FRC robot project is a structured codebase that contains all the code needed to control your robot. WPILib provides project templates that give you a starting point with the correct structure and configuration. Understanding how to create and configure projects is essential for FRC development.

Learn more: WPILib Documentation: Creating a Robot Project

sections.title: Project Templates Available
sections.subtitle: WPILib provides several project templates:
items: TimedRobot: Simple template with basic robot lifecycle methods (best for beginners)
Command Robot: Full command-based programming framework (recommended for most teams)
Command Robot (Skeleton): Minimal command-based template with less boilerplate
Example Projects: Pre-built examples demonstrating various features

sections.title: Creating a New Project
sections.content:
The easiest way to create a new FRC project is using the WPILib VS Code extension. This ensures your project is properly configured with all necessary files and dependencies.

Steps to Create a Project:

1. Open VS Code: Launch Visual Studio Code (installed with WPILib).

2. Open Command Palette: Press Ctrl+Shift+P (Windows/Linux) or Cmd+Shift+P (Mac) to open the command palette.

3. Select Create Project: Type 'WPILib: Create a new project' and select it from the list.

4. Choose Template: Select your project type (TimedRobot or Command Robot).

5. Select Language: Choose Java (recommended for beginners).

6. Enter Team Number: Enter your FRC team number (e.g., 1234). This is important for network configuration.

7. Name Your Project: Enter a descriptive name (e.g., 'Robot2024').

8. Choose Location: Select where to save your project folder.

9. Create Project: Click 'Generate Project' and wait for the project to be created.

sections.title: Project Structure Overview
sections.content:
A WPILib project has a specific directory structure that organizes your code and configuration files. Understanding this structure helps you navigate and organize your robot code effectively.

Root Directory: Contains configuration files and project metadata
src/main/java/: Your Java source code goes here
vendordeps/: Third-party library dependencies (CTRE, REV, etc.)
.wpilib/: WPILib-specific configuration
build.gradle: Build configuration and dependencies
settings.gradle: Gradle project settings

sections.title: Project Directory Structure
sections.content:
YourProjectName/
├── .wpilib/                    # WPILib configuration
│   └── wpilib_preferences.json  # Team number and preferences
├── src/
│   └── main/
│       ├── java/               # Java source code
│       │   └── frc/
│       │       └── robot/
│       │           ├── Main.java        # Entry point
│       │           ├── Robot.java       # Main robot class
│       │           └── RobotContainer.java  # Command-based config
│       └── deploy/             # Deploy configuration files
├── vendordeps/                  # Vendor dependencies
├── build.gradle                 # Build configuration
├── settings.gradle              # Gradle settings
└── gradlew                      # Gradle wrapper script

sections.title: Key Files Explained
sections.content:
Each file in your project has a specific purpose. Understanding these files helps you work effectively with your robot code.

Main.java: The entry point of your program. It calls the Robot class and handles program initialization.

Robot.java (TimedRobot): The main robot class that extends TimedRobot. Contains methods like robotInit(), autonomousPeriodic(), and teleopPeriodic() that are called at different times during robot operation.

RobotContainer.java (Command-based): Central configuration class for command-based programming. Sets up subsystems, commands, and button bindings.

Constants.java: A file (you may need to create) for storing constant values like motor IDs, speeds, and configuration parameters.

Learn more: WPILib Documentation: Project Structure

sections.title: Basic TimedRobot Template Structure
build.gradle File Overview
sections.content:
The build.gradle file is the heart of your project's build configuration. It defines dependencies, plugins, and build settings. While you don't need to understand every detail, knowing the basics helps when adding vendor libraries or troubleshooting build issues.

Key Sections:
- Plugins: WPILib, Java, and other build plugins
- Repositories: Where to download dependencies from
- Dependencies: Libraries your code uses (WPILib, CTRE, REV, etc.)
- WPILib Version: Specifies which version of WPILib to use

Learn more: WPILib Documentation: Third-Party Libraries

sections.title: Example build.gradle Structure
Team Number Configuration
sections.content:
Your team number is crucial for network communication between your computer and robot. It's used to configure the robot's network settings and must be set correctly in your project.

Where Team Number is Stored: The team number is stored in .wpilib/wpilib_preferences.json. This file is automatically created when you create a project with a team number.

Changing Team Number: You can change the team number by:
1. Opening .wpilib/wpilib_preferences.json
2. Editing the teamNumber field
3. Or using the WPILib VS Code command: 'WPILib: Set Team Number'

Why It Matters: The team number determines the robot's IP address on the network. Incorrect team numbers prevent communication between your computer and robot.

sections.title: Building the Project
sections.content:
Building your project compiles your Java code into a format that can run on the roboRIO. The WPILib VS Code extension provides easy ways to build your project.

Building Methods:

1. Using VS Code Command:
- Press Ctrl+Shift+P and type 'WPILib: Build Robot Code'
- Or use the keyboard shortcut Ctrl+Shift+B

2. Using Terminal:
- Open the integrated terminal in VS Code
- Run ./gradlew build (Windows: gradlew.bat build)

3. Using Build Task:
- Go to Terminal → Run Build Task
- Select 'WPILib: Build Robot Code'

If the build succeeds, you'll see 'BUILD SUCCESSFUL' in the output. Any errors will be displayed with file names and line numbers.

sections.title: Deploying to Robot
sections.content:
Deploying uploads your compiled code to the roboRIO (robot controller). The robot must be powered on and connected to the same network as your computer.

Deployment Methods:

1. Using VS Code Command:
- Press Ctrl+Shift+P and type 'WPILib: Deploy Robot Code'
- Or use the keyboard shortcut Ctrl+F5

2. Using Terminal:
- Run ./gradlew deploy (Windows: gradlew.bat deploy)

Deployment Process:
1. Builds your project (if not already built)
2. Connects to the robot over the network
3. Uploads the compiled code
4. Restarts the robot code on the roboRIO

Verification: After deployment, check the Driver Station to see if the robot code is running. You should see your robot's status indicators active.

Learn more: WPILib Documentation: roboRIO Introduction

sections.title: Project Configuration Best Practices
sections.subtitle: For well-organized projects:
items: Use descriptive project names that indicate the season or purpose
Set your team number correctly during project creation
Organize code into packages (subsystems, commands, etc.)
Use a Constants class for configuration values
Keep build.gradle updated with correct WPILib version
Use version control (Git) to track changes
Document your code with comments
Keep project structure consistent across team members
Test project creation and deployment before competition

sections.title: Project Lifecycle
sections.content:
Understanding the project lifecycle helps you work efficiently:

1. Create: Use WPILib template to create project structure
2. Develop: Write and modify code in the src/main/java/ directory
3. Build: Compile code to check for errors
4. Deploy: Upload code to robot for testing
5. Test: Run code on robot and verify behavior
6. Iterate: Make changes and repeat the cycle

This cycle repeats throughout development. Building frequently catches errors early, and deploying regularly ensures your code works on the actual robot hardware.

sections.title: Troubleshooting Project Issues
sections.subtitle: Common problems and solutions:
items: Project Creation Fails: Ensure WPILib is installed, VS Code extension is active, restart VS Code
Build Errors: Check Java syntax, review error messages in build output
Deployment Fails: Verify robot is powered and connected, check team number, check firewall
Code Not Running: Verify deployment succeeded, check Driver Station status, verify robot mode
Dependencies Missing: Ensure vendor libraries are in build.gradle and vendordeps folder
Team Number Wrong: Update team number in .wpilib/wpilib_preferences.json
Network Issues: Verify robot IP address matches team number pattern
Build Cache Issues: Run ./gradlew clean and rebuild
Java Version Mismatch: Verify Java version in build.gradle matches installed JDK
